Some people have begun to regularly use AI in their workflows, others have gone further, integrating it into their cognitive routines and creative identities. For many people, the moment feels strange and unsettling. They don't know how, when and whether to invest in AI. There is a growing sense that work, as they have known it, is receding.

articles.summary: JPMorgan warns that the next recession could be different for white-collar knowledge workers. Since the late 1980s, jobs that focus on routine tasks have been disappearing because of automation. For the first time, workers from non-routine cognitive occupations now account for a greater share of the unemployed than workers from manual jobs.

articles.title: OpenAI's head of ChatGPT shares the one trait you need to be successful at the company
articles.author: system
articles.summary: ChatGPT just got a boost to its memory. Nick Turley, head of ChatGPT, said it's those who can build "from scratch" who succeed at OpenAI.    The company looks for this quality in new hires and even tests for it.

articles.title: Gooners Say Their Brains Are Becoming Hopelessly Hijacked by AI Smut
articles.author: Futurism
articles.summary: AI-generated adult content is already becoming a problem for some men. Kyle, 26, went down the AI smut rabbit hole after stumbling upon a woman with large breasts the size of her body. He urges others to avoid it at all costs.

articles.title: AI and the human connection
articles.author: Thomas A. Hemphill
articles.summary: In April, AI chatbot company Joi AI surveyed 2,000 Gen Z individuals, those born between 1997 and 2012. According to the survey, 83% of respondents say they can form a deep emotional bond with an AI-generated partner and 80% would marry an AI partner. 75% believe AI partners have the potential to replace human companionship fully.
